conclusion: Two particles, A and B, start moving from rest in the same direction. The problem asks for the ratio of the magnitudes of acceleration during their deceleration phases.

The image shows a velocity-time graph for particles A and B. Both start from rest and move in a straight line. Particle A increases velocity to 2v0 over t0, then decreases to 0 over 3t0. Particle B increases to 2v0 over t0, maintains it over 4t0, then decreases to 0 over 5t0.
The acceleration of a particle is determined by the slope of its velocity-time graph.
For particle A, the deceleration phase occurs from 2v0 to 0 over 3t0. The slope is -2v0/3t0.
For particle B, the deceleration phase occurs from 2v0 to 0 over 5t0. The slope is -2v0/5t0.
The magnitude of acceleration is the absolute value of the slope.
For particle A, the magnitude of acceleration during deceleration is 2v0/3t0.
For particle B, the magnitude of acceleration during deceleration is 2v0/5t0.
The ratio of the magnitudes of acceleration for A and B is (2v0/3t0) / (2v0/5t0) = 5/3.
The ratio of the magnitudes of acceleration for A and B during their deceleration phases is 5/3.
